2, (pg 40)
Topic: Leisure time
How people spend their time at work: people in workplaces where efficiency is number one value that people have to increase their efficiency. Filling spead up, filling their life on workplaces, fear of not having enough times for relax.
First way people organize leisure time: Value the efficiency. These sides make people spend time on those, like walking around, or learning about tour side, instead of spending time slowly, people drive arround with played camera out the window, or playing efficiently as they work.
Second way people organize leisure time: Multitasks. Do leisure activities as much as possible in limitted amount of times. People are able to fill 11 leisure hours in 7 actual hours. Technology make leisure time possible like work time. 
People are hurry at work and tired at home, leisure time in low energy choices.
Number 1 leisure activity is watching Tv, some people as so tired that they become couch potatoes – means want to sit in couch and do nothing but watching Tv – as response to stress.

tokenization.input_text:
Summarize this text: : We are about to see the greatest redistribution of power in history.
Over millennia, humanity has been shaped by successive waves of technology. The discovery of fire, the invention of the wheel, the harnessing of electricity—all were transformational moments for civilization. All were waves of technology that started small, with a few precarious experiments, but eventually they broke across the world. These waves followed a similar trajectory: breakthrough technologies were invented, delivered huge value, and so they proliferated, became more effective, cheaper, more widespread and were absorbed into the normal, ever-evolving fabric of human life. 
We are now facing a new wave of technology, centered around AI but including synthetic biology, quantum computing, and abundant new sources of energy. In many respects it will repeat this pattern. Yet it will also depart from it in crucial ways only now becoming clear. Amidst all the hype, the hope, the fear, I think the fundamentals are getting lost; the unique characteristics of this wave are getting missed in the noise. Understanding them, seeing what, exactly, is changing, is critical to understanding the future.

If we as a sector can’t take full advantage of the possibilities of big �data, then who can? �Yet we only have to look around us, at the blunt use of metrics such as journal �impact factors, h-indices and grant income targets to be reminded of the ’s �pitfalls. Some of the most precious qualities of academic culture resist simple quantification, and individual indicators can struggle to do justice to the richness and plurality of our research.
